question.title: Predicates and functions
question.body:
public static void main(String[] args) {
    List<String> strings = Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c", "d");

    strings.stream()
            .filter(s -> test(s, "temp"))
            .map(s -> transform(s, "temp"))
            .filter(s -> anotherTest())
            .map(s -> anotherTransform())
            .count();
}

public static boolean test(String s1, String s2) {
    return s1.equals(s2);
}

public static String transform(String s1, String s2) {
    return s1 + s2;
}

public static boolean anotherTest() {
    return true;
}

public static String anotherTransform() {
    return "temp";
}

Considering the code given above, I am confused as to how I am able to pass test method that returns a boolean but accepts two arguments for filter in place of a Predicate and transform method for map in place of a Function. It also works for methods with no arguments like anotherTest and anotherTransform and it's really confusing.

Does only the return type matter for predicates and functions and not the number of arguments?
